title: LONGEVITY LEAVE FOR ASSIDUITY

eligibility.description: Permanent public service employees at the state level, assigned to:
eligibility.requirement: Must have completed five uninterrupted years of effective service.

how_to_apply: Wait for the publication of the ordinance outlining the necessary requirements for approval.
Access the RH BAHIA system and submit your request in the requests tab.
where_to_apply: At SAC Education service centers in Salvador/Feira de Santana
At the Territorial Education Center (NTE) of the jurisdiction where the employee is assigned.
application_deadline: As indicated in the publication ordinance.

procedures_after_completion.enjoyment: At the end of the leave period, the employee must report to their assigned unit and/or complement, and ensure that the reassumption document is sent to the Human Resources Administration Directorate / Coordination of Provision and Mobility / Temporary Leave Coordination.
procedures_after_completion.compensation: The employee does not need to take leave, as the payment is made directly to the registered bank account.

responsible_unit: Human Resources Administration Directorate (DIREH) / Coordination of Provision and Mobility (CPM) / Temporary Leave Coordination (CAT), in the case of enjoyment.
general_information: The employee must remain active while awaiting approval of the leave by the competent authority (publication in the State Official Gazette).
Double counting for retirement is guaranteed for five-year periods completed until 12/15/1998.
In the case of holding multiple positions, even within the same institution, the longevity leave must be requested separately for each position.
interruption_conditions: Leave for treating a family member's health
Conviction to a prison sentence by final judgment
Leave to accompany spouse or partner
Unjustified absences exceeding 15 days per year or 45 days per five-year period
rights: The right to longevity leave does not expire and is not subject to forfeiture.

legal_basis.description: Article 41, sections XVIII, XXVII, and XXVIII of the State Constitution.
Articles 107 to 110 of Law 6.677 of September 26, 1994.
